Fig. 1 Representation of the Schiff-base functionalized NiCl2 nano-systems employed herein. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) Representation of the achieved percentage conversion at various time intervals; (b) The evaluated activities (TONs) of the salicylaldimine (NP1.1—1.4) and iminopyridine (NP2.1–2.4) nano-catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Representative FT-IR (ATR) spectrum of the catalytically achieved polystyrene. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Representative 1H NMR spectrum of the catalytically achieved polystyrene. Nano polymerization catalysts: Further insights into nanoparticle-facilitated polymerization of olefins Wilhelm Heinrich le Roux Data curation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Albert J. van Reenen Writing – review & editing Rehana Malgas-Enus Conceptualization Funding acquisition Investigation Methodology Project administration Resources Software Supervision Validation Visualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ Stellenbosch University, Department of Chemistry and Polymer Science, Private Bag X1, Matieland, 7602 Stellenbosch, South Africa Stellenbosch University, Department of Chemistry and Polymer Science Private Bag X1, Matieland Stellenbosch 7602 South Africa Stellenbosch University, Department of Chemistry and Polymer Science, Private Bag X1, Matieland, 7602, Stellenbosch, South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Based on recent developments on the use of Schiff-base functionalized nickel nanoparticles as pre-catalysts in the polymerization of norbornene, the potential of these nano-systems was further explored using other olefins, both aromatic and aliphatic olefins. Herein, Schiff-base functionalized NiCl2 nanoparticles were further evaluated as potential coordination polymerization catalysts for styrene employing modified methylaluminoxane (MMAO) as a co-catalyst. Furthermore, the first attempted co-polymerization of styrene with α-linear olefins (C5-C9) using nanoparticle-assisted transformation is reported. It was found that the nano-catalysts were capable of the coordination polymerization and co-oligomerization of styrene and gave relatively monodispersed medium molecular weight polymers and short chained co-oligomers with activities comparable to the complex analogs. It was further shown that the activity of the nano-catalysts as well as the Mw and PDI of the polymers/oligomers, were not dependent on the Schiff-base ligand used as capping agent nor its concentration. The nano-catalysts were also shown to exhibit stereocontrol, giving isotactic-rich atactic homo- and co-polymers. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Schiff-base nickel nanoparticles Nanoparticle-assisted polymerization α-olefin co-oligomerization Styrene coordination polymerization 1 Introduction Considering the recent report of polymerization and oligomerization of a cyclic olefin through nanoparticle-assisted transformations, there arose a need to evaluate the scope of nanoparticle-facilitated polymerization [1]. The reported nano-system has been seen to afford high catalytic conversions with low polydispersity indices (Đ). These observations have shown that it is not necessary for catalytic activity to come at the detriment of catalytic control. However, due to the novelty of these nano-polymerization catalysts, a full understanding of their catalytic scope is lacking. Therefore, to better understand the catalytic range of the nano-catalyst, their use as polymerization catalysts of acyclic α-olefins was evaluated. Styrene is an aromatic acyclic α-olefin of which millions of tons are produced annually [2]. Styrene has been reported to possess both carcinogenic and mutagenic properties [3]. It is transformed by the human metabolic system into predominantly styrene oxide, where it is further enzymatically metabolized [4]. Therefore, the conversion of styrene to biologically safe and chemically useful alternatives has constituted an essential part of the commercial production line since 1839. One of the chemically useful alternatives is the polymerization of styrene to polystyrene (PS). Polystyrene is an inexpensive, low density, high chemical- and heat resistant polymer, and has been utilized as a plastic, packaging materials, rubbers, insulators, fiberglass, electronics, and in automobile production [4–7]. It is also a non-biodegradable, but recyclable, pollutant which is greatly contributing to global plastic pollution [3]. Despite being a pollutant, the lack of any viable alternative with the intrinsic properties of polystyrene, as well as its excellent commercial value, means that it nevertheless remains an invaluable part of daily life. Polystyrene can be attained in three forms, namely syndiotactic- (sPS), isotactic- (iPS) and atactic polystyrene (aPS) [8]. The form of polystyrene obtained is dependent on the catalytic conditions employed. The use of discrete titanium complexes in conjunction with methylaluminoxane (MAO) as co-catalyst generally affords polystyrene with a high degree of syndiotacticity, with a characteristic melting temperature (T m) of 270 ℃ [8–10]. Discrete complexes of nickel with MAO purvey isotactic-rich atactic polystyrene which lacks a characteristic melting point [8,11]. The exploration of possible useful transformations for linear α-olefins has become an extensive part of academic research. Linear α-olefins are side products from the Fischer-Tropsch industrial process and are classified as industrial waste [12]. Oxidation [13], hydroformylation [14,15], and hydroaminomethylation are the predominant transformation reactions for linear α-olefins [16,17], resulting in commercially and industrially viable products. These viable products include lubricants, waxes, and surfactants. Homopolymerization of linear α-olefins, however, is much less predominant in the literature. Reports found in the literature show obtainable linear homopolymers utilizing Ziegler-Natta type coordination catalysts, however, the catalytic reaction conditions generally require the use of low or elevated temperatures and results in average catalytic activities with increased polydispersities [18–20]. Therefore, given both the importance as well as the difficulty of their transformations, the development of catalysts capable of successfully transforming the linear α-olefins through homo- or co-polymerization process are of great importance. Furthermore, limited reports for the use of nickel catalysts in the coordination polymerization of linear α-olefins were found [68–70] . Here, we present the coordination polymerization of styrene and linear α-olefins through nickel nanoparticle-facilitated transformation with modified MAO (MMAO) as co-catalyst. Additionally, we evaluated whether the nano-catalysts can facilitate multiple substrates, by testing the co-polymerization of styrene with C5-C9 linear α-olefins. The molecular weight (Mw) and polydispersity (Đ) properties of the homo- and co-polymers are reported as determined by gel-permeation-size exclusion chromatography (GPC-SEC) with THF as eluent. The tacticity and therefore the stereocontrol of the homo- and co-polymers were probed using 13C- nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectroscopy. Lastly, the catalytic activity of the nano-catalysts was compared to the discrete complex analogs in the literature used for polymerization transformations. 2 Experimental materials and methods 2.1 Materials for Schiff-base nickel nanoparticle synthesis The 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. The n-propylamine was purchased from SRL Chemical and used as received. The nickel chloride hexahydrate was purchased from Merck and used as received. The hydrazine monohydrate was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. 2.2 Materials for homo- and co-polymerization Modified methylaluminoxane-12 (MMAO-12), 7% solution in toluene, was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without purification. Toluene was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and further purified using a toluene purifier. Styrene (96%) was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. The linear α-olefins i.e., 1-hexene (99%), 1-heptene (97%), 1-octene (98%) and 1-nonene (96%) were all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, whereas 1-pentene (95%) was purchased from Arcos Organics and used without purification. 2.3 Analytical characterization methods UV-Vis spectroscopy was performed on a Shimadzu Spectrophotometer UV-1800. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using an Oxford Agilent NMR spectrometer at 400 MHz, with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard and using a T 1 = 2 s. Room temperature 1H- and 13C NMR was performed at 25 ℃ in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3). FT-IR spectroscopy was performed on a Nicolet Avatar 330 FTIR spectrophotometer, using the attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode. ICP-AES was performed on Spectro Arcos FHS 12 spectrometer. HR-TEM analysis was performed at the University of Western Cape. Room temperature GPC-SEC was performed on the homopolymers and co-oligomers and were analyzed at the Polymer Science division at Stellenbosch University, South Africa. The homopolymers and co-oligomers were analyzed at Stellenbosch University using THF (0.125% BHT stabilizer) as eluent at 1.0 mL.min−1 on a PL Gel column, 300 × 7.5 mm i.d., (Agilent technologies, US) and a PL Gel pre-column, 50 × 7.5 mm i.d., with differential 410 diffractometer (Waters, US) and 2487 dual wavelength absorbance UV/Vis detector (Waters, US) at 25 ℃ using narrow polystyrene as standard (580–2,000,000 g.mol−1). Calculation of the absolute molar masses was performed using the Astra Software (Wyatt technology, US). The refractive index increment dn/dc was calculated from the RI signal with an average value of 0.037 mL/g for all polymers. 2.4 Standard polymerization and oligomerization procedure [21,22] Due to the air-sensitive nature of the co-catalyst, all experiments were carried out in a glovebox using standard Schlenk techniques. The required volume of purified toluene was added to the Schlenk tube and was subsequently sealed in the glovebox where 0.358 g of MMAO was added in a pseudo “2000:1″ Al:Ni ratio. Exactly, 9.3 µmol of the appropriate nickel nano-catalyst was added to the Schlenk containing the toluene solution. Subsequently, 1.479 g of styrene was added to the reaction vessel directly using a syringe, initiating the polymerization reaction. For the co-oligomerization, a total mass of 1.497 g was used in a 1:1 styrene:linear olefin ratio. The final volume for all reactions was kept constant at 25 mL. The reaction continued for four hours at room temperature. After the reaction was completed, it was stopped and added directly to 150 mL acidic methanol (95:5). The PS precipitated as a white solid and was stirred in the acidic methanol for two hours prior to isolation and drying in a 60 ℃ oven. All nanoparticle synthesis methodologies and full characterization was reported by le Roux et al.1 Nano-systems, NP1.1 - NP1.4 and NP2.1 -NP2.4, as seen in Table 1 were synthesized using the general synthesis procedures as described below at varying M:L ratios. 2.5 General synthesis procedure for salicylaldimine capped Ni-NPs (NP1.1-1.4) Salicylaldimine, L1, (0.1375 g, 0.84 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) in a 100 mL round-bottom flask at ambient conditions. Nickel chloride hexahydrate (0.1033 g, 0.43 mmol) was added to the solution. The solution was reduced using hydrazine monohydrate (0.270 mL, 8.4 mmol) in a 1:20 nickel:hydrazine ratio and refluxed for 18 h at 60 ℃ . The precipitate was allowed to settle out, the ethanol was removed using a syringe and subsequently washed with fresh ethanol thrice. Excess ethanol was removed using rotary evaporation, a beige solid residue remained. The solid was dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature. Yield 101 mg; FTIR (ATR, cm−1): ν (O-H) 3269 ν (=C-H) 3080; ν (CN) 1634; ν (C-O) 1311; UV-Vis (nm): 418 (Surface Plasmon Resonance). 2.6 General synthesis procedure for 2-iminopyridine capped Ni-NPs (NP2.1-2.4) 2-iminopyridine, L2, (0.3837 g, 2.6 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) in a 100 mL round-bottom flask at ambient conditions. Nickel chloride hexahydrate (0.3024 g, 1.3 mmol) was added to the solution. The solution was reduced using hydrazine monohydrate (0.816 mL, 25.5 mmol) in a 1:20 nickel:hydrazine ratio and refluxed for 18 h at 60 ℃ . The precipitate was allowed to settle out, the ethanol was removed using a syringe and subsequently washed with fresh ethanol, thrice. Excess ethanol was removed using rotary evaporation, a red/pink solid residue remained. The solid was dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature. Yield 89 mg; FTIR (ATR, cm−1): ν (=C-H) 3101; ν (CN) 1621; ν (Cl-Cl) 1589; ν (C-N) 1321; UV-Vis (nm): 388 (Surface Plasmon Resonance). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Schiff-base nickel nano-catalysts Salicylaldimine- and iminopyridine functionalized Ni-NPs were synthesized, fully characterized, and evaluated as reported by le Roux et al [1]. ( Fig. 1). These systems comprised of NiCl2 functionalized nanoparticles with a varied metal to ligand (M:L) ratio ranging from 1:1–1:4. The nanomaterials were fully characterized with Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy; UV-Visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma – atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) as well as high resolution – transition electron microscopy (HR-TEM).1 From the HR-TEM, no NPs were found within the micrographs, suggesting that the NPs are below the spatial resolution of the TEM instrument i.e., below 2 nm in diameter. Table 1 defines the range of NPs employed as pre-catalysts for polymerization. Due to the novelty and catalytic abilities of the nanomaterials, we aimed to further explore the capabilities of the nano-catalysts in the coordinative homo- and co-polymerization of styrene with linear α-olefins (LAOs), to better understand the catalytic range available to these nano-catalysts. 3.2 Nanoparticle-assisted coordination polymerization of styrene Metallocene facilitated coordination polymerization of styrene has been well reported in the literature using MAO as co-catalyst [23–26]. Based on this, to fully gauge the catalytic capabilities of the functionalized nano-catalysts, a range of parameters were investigated during the coordination polymerization of styrene. The effect of reaction time, ligand choice, and temperature were investigated. Firstly, optimization of the reaction time at room temperature with NP1.2 was conducted to evaluate the required time for the full conversion of styrene to PS to be achieved. For this investigation, the reaction was halted after 2-, 3-, 4-, 6- and 24-hours intervals ( Fig. 2a; Table 2). Despite a small increase in percentage conversion of 9% between two and three hours, an exponential increase of 34% was observed between three and four hours. Furthermore, at six hours, percentage conversions greater than 90% was achieved, indicating full conversion occurred at six hours. Secondly, because the literature is dominated with styrene polymerization reactions performed at ≥ 50 ℃ [24,26–28], the effect of this elevated temperature on the catalytic conversions were evaluated. One of our nano-catalysts i.e., NP1.2 was therefore tested at 50 ℃ for two hours. From the temperature study it was observed that the catalytic prowess of our nano-catalysts is temperature dependent as expected [24], giving full conversion at 50 ℃ at a third of the reaction time required for the room temperature reactions. However, as our aim is to report on the most cost-effective catalyst systems and reaction conditions, the remainder of the catalytic reaction reported herein were performed at room temperature conditions at four hours. Lastly, the effect on the catalytic polymerization based on the choice of ligand, were investigated through the comparison of the salicylaldimine (NP1) and iminopyridine (NP2) functionalized nano-systems (Fig. 2b; Table 2). Furthermore, the effect of the M:L ratio in a 1:1–1:4 range were also investigated. It was observed that the iminopyridine functionalized nano-catalysts except for the NP2.2 system, catalytically outperformed the salicylaldimine nano-systems on average, with 45.3 kg of polymer/molNi. From the achieved activities, it was evident that styrene polymerization was highly ligand dependent, despite the small difference in activity between the 1:1 systems. The low ligand concentration of the 1:1 systems was responsible for the negligible difference in the 1:1 systems as the scarcity of ligand on the nano-surface resulted in a low steric environment. The low steric environment means that few of the active sites are blocked by the presence of the ligand and therefore the activity was high [30,31]. Increased ligand concentration resulted in a decreased activity independent of the ligand employed. This is due to the increased M:L ratio which increases the steric crowding on the nano-surface. Increased steric crowding results in increased active site blocking by the ligands, making less of the active sites accessible to olefin insertion [30,31]. Interestingly, for the iminopyridine systems (NP2.1 - 2.4) the achieved activity obtained at the 1:3 and 1:4 M:L ratios were comparable to that of the 1:1 systems, indicating that the increased steric crowding on the nano-surface has a lessened effect at these higher M:L ratios. For the salicylaldimine systems (NP1.1 - 1.4), the increased M:L at all ratios decreased the achieved activity as expected due to the increased steric crowding. A plausible reason for the trend observed for the iminopyridine systems (NP2.1 - 2.4) could be the favorable release of steric strain on the nano-surface [32–34]. As the iminopyridine ligand (L2) is a bidentate N,N-donor solely coordinated to the nano-surface and not through covalent bonding. This bidentate nature increases the steric strain on the nano-surface significantly more than for the monodentate salicylaldimine ligand (L1). Therefore, due to its weak coordinating bonds as well as the favorable energetics of releasing the steric strain on the nano-surface at higher M:L ratios [30], this becomes more favorable because as they dissociate, the available active sites increase, resulting in the increased activity observed [32–34]. It was clearly observed that the iminopyridine systems (NP2.1 - 2.4) fully converted the styrene to PS within four hours which is less than the expected six hours, speaking to the highly active nature of iminopyridine functionalized nano-catalysts. Lastly, it is essential to conclude that the nano-catalysts evaluated, regardless of the ligand, in all cases are comparable to the styrene polymerization catalysts in the literature. Moreover, in some instances our nano-catalysts outcompetes the reported catalysts under reduced reaction conditions [27,35,37]. 3.3 Characterization of polystyrene To evaluate and identify the converted product, the molecular weight (Mw), polydispersity index (Đ), and tacticity; an array of characterization techniques were employed. These characterization techniques were FT-IR spectroscopy, 1H- and 13C- nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, gel-permeation size exclusion chromatography (GPC-SEC); UV-Vis spectroscopy, and melting point analysis. From the FT-IR spectroscopic analysis ( Fig. 3), successful conversion of styrene to PS was confirmed. This confirmation was based on the following observations: the aromatic C-H stretching frequencies at 3081–3023 cm−1 corresponding to the phenyl moiety. The emergence of the methylene C-H stretching frequencies at 2919–2846 cm−1 confirmed the conversion of the styrene alkene to the PS alkane bridge. The CC stretching frequencies of the phenyl moiety at 1600 cm−1, 1582 cm−1, 1492 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 was also observed. The presence of the 756 cm−1 and 694 cm−1 C-H out-of-plane bending frequencies indicated singular substitution of the phenyl moieties [39,40]. From the 1H NMR spectrum ( Fig. 4) the low intensity proton signals in the 5.2–6.7 ppm olefin range was confirmatory of the conversion of the styrene to the PS as well as providing evidence that β-H abstraction is the chain transfer reaction. Furthermore, the presence of signal multiplets as opposed to the presence of fine signals is indicative of polymeric molecules. The experimentally achieved 1H NMR spectra obtained within this investigation corresponded very well to the literature on PS [41,42]. To correlate the obtained 1H NMR results, 13C NMR analysis was performed ( Fig. 5). The presence of signals at ± 20 ppm and ± 40–45 ppm corresponds to the methyl and methylene/methine moieties, respectfully. The upfield location of these signals are due to the loss of the styrene olefin and the emergence of the aliphatic bridge in PS. A shift in the substituted carbon signal from ± 136 ppm to ± 146 ppm was observed. Furthermore, the compression of the olefin methine and methylene signals at ± 135 ppm and ± 114 ppm and the emergence of the aliphatic methine and methylene signals at ± 40 ppm, undoubtedly, confirmed the successful conversion to PS as well as providing evidence of β-H abstraction transfer reactions [43]. Subsequently, the tacticity of the polymeric product was investigated via 13C NMR and melting point analysis. According to the work published by Cheng et al [44]. the presence of the multiplet of signals at ± 146 ppm and ± 44 ppm in place of a singlets is indicative of variations in the PS microstructures, implying variable tacticity. These observed satellites are a result of the variable tacticity of the methylene carbons. The isotactic (mm)-, heterotactic (mr)- and syndiotactic (rr) triads at 146.1, 145.7 and 145.2 ppm, respectively, were assigned [45]. The assignments made in the 1H- and 13C NMR spectra indicated that the PS product was isotactic-rich atactic PS. Obtaining isotactic-rich PS was expected as nickel catalysts tend to produce PS with this tacticity [8,11,45]. Subsequently, the weight percentage (%weight) of the isotactic, syndiotactic and atactic sub-sequences of the PS chains were determined using 13C NMR. From 13C NMR analysis using Eq. (1), it was found that the coordination polymers were comprised of ± 54.3% isotactic PS, 21.2%. Equation 1: Formula for the determination of percentage tacticity as determined by 13 C NMR Tacticity ( % ) = Integration of mm / mr / rr ∑ integration of mm + mr + rr × 100 syndiotactic PS and 24.4% atactic PS, sub-sequences. The determined composition based on the meso triads in the PS NMR spectrum corresponds well with the reported literature of nickel transformed PS [11,45]. The formation of three PS microstructures i.e., iPS, sPS and aPS were observed. The formation of aPS is due to the non-specific nickel catalytic species or MAO [46], whereas, iPS and sPS are due to iso- and syndiospecific nickel active species, respectively [47]. It was confirmed that no abnormal polymerization configurations such as tail-tail or head-head growth was present in the PS product based on the 13C NMR analysis [48,49]. To confirm the tacticity of the PS, melting point analysis in the 50–350 ℃ range was performed. From the melting point analysis, a glass transition temperature (T g ) of 100 ℃ was observed with minute deviations in the PS products. Unexpectedly, a melting point for some of the PS products was also observed at ± 240 ℃ . The observation of a T m at 240 ℃ indicated a degree of semi-crystallinity in the sample corresponding to the melting of the isotactic/syndiotactic-rich regions of the PS chain [2,50]. This showed that for some of the PS products, longer iso- and syndiotactic sub-sequences were present which allowed for the formation of crystal lamellae [51]. Therefore, the melting point as well as the 13C NMR analysis indicated that the PS was isotactic-rich atactic PS. This indicated that although the nanoparticles were capable of stereoselective control, it was not capable of exhibiting this control throughout the propagating polymer chain. To determine the molecular weight (Mw) and polydispersity index (PDI, Đ) of the coordinated polymer chains, room temperature GPC-SEC (THF as eluent) was performed using polystyrene as reference standard. In certain cases, the polymer products did not show full solubility in THF after 24 h of dissolution and was filtered prior to analysis. The slight insolubility of the polymeric products in THF are due to the isotactic-rich nature of the polymer. The SEC analysis showed that for all the PS products medium molecular weights with low PDIs were achieved. The low PDIs obtained, proved the nano-catalysts exhibited a high degree of control during polymerization, with the obtained PDIs comparable to the metallocene analogs used for styrene polymerization in the literature [27,37,45]. Firstly, the effect of reaction time on the chain length and PDI was investigated. Similar molecular weights of ± 45 000 g.mol−1 was observed independent of the reaction time, with a negligible increase to ± 47 000 g.mol−1 after 24 h ( Fig. 6a-b; Table 3). The time independence observed, indicated that a fixed chain length of 20,000–40,000 g.mol−1can be facilitated by the catalyst irrespective of the reaction time. This is due to steric crowding on the nano-surface. Once the steric crowding caused by the propagating polymeric chain becomes too great, the chain undergoes a transfer reaction through β-H abstraction [52,53]. Evidence of β-H abstraction is found in the 1H- and 13C NMR spectra of the PS products. In the 1H NMR spectra, low intensity proton signals corresponding to olefin protons are observed at ± 4.0 ppm and in the ± 6.0–5.0 ppm range, whereas in the 13C NMR, the signal at ± 136 ppm is indicative of the olefin [41]. When investigating the effect of an elevated temperature of 50 ℃ , a distinct 39% decrease in the molecular weight was observed in comparison to the reaction performed at room temperature. The shorter obtained chain length is due to the excess heat provided to the system, as elevated temperatures are well known for promoting β-H abstraction and therefore increasing the rate of chain termination [54]. Lastly, the effect of the ligand-type and the ligand concentration on the coordination polymer product was evaluated (Fig. 6c-d; Table 3). As reported by us previously, a strong ligand dependency on the molecular weight achieved was expected, with increased chain length because of the increased stabilization of the nanoparticle active sites through the disruption of the β-agostic interaction between the propagating polymer chain and the ligand [1]. However, this was not observed with styrene, showing an independency to the ligand-type and the ligand density on the nano-surface. The observed ligand independency for styrene as a monomer, implies that a β-agostic interaction between the propagating PS chains and the ligand is not present. This would imply that the nanoparticle active site is optimally stable for controlled chain propagation [30,31]. The PDIs were independent of the ligand employed or the ligand concentration in the nano-system. That implies that the nano-catalysts have intrinsic control that they exhibit over the propagating chains and is not influenced by the ligand or its concentration. This further implies that additional steric crowding caused by the increased ligand concentration (as M:L increases), does not improve the stability of the active site as expected according to known literature [52,53]. From the results it was shown that our nano-catalysts are cost-effective and highly active polymerization catalysts at reduced reaction conditions compared to some of the discrete complex analogs. A proposed nanoparticle polymerization mechanism is presented in Scheme 1. Although, Schiff-base nickel catalysts have been reported to facilitate chain walking, based on the characterization of the polystyrene products, no chain walking seemed to be present in the polymer microstructure. 3.4 Co-oligomerization of styrene with C5-C9 Following the promising results obtained for the coordination polymerization of styrene, the coordination polymerization of linear α-olefins (LAO) was subsequently attempted. Upon attempting the homopolymerization of the LAO, it was found that the nano-catalysts were unable to facilitate their transformation to polyolefins. This was owed to the property of LAOs to resist homopolymerization due to their low reactivity ratios [55,56]. Therefore, co-polymerization of styrene with these LAOs i.e., 1-pentene, 1-hexene, 1-heptene, 1-octene and 1-nonene, was attempted ( Fig. 7). The co-polymerization was performed under identical conditions as for the coordinated homopolymerization as described in the experimental section [21,22]. The NP2.1 nano-catalyst was selected for this investigation due to exhibiting the greatest catalytic activity during the coordinated homopolymerization of styrene. The resulting co-polymers were characterized using FT-IR (ATR) spectroscopy ( Fig. 8), 1H- and 13C NMR spectroscopy ( Fig. 9a - b), melting point analysis and UV-Vis spectroscopy. To determine whether oligomerization or polymerization was the active mechanism for the co-polymers, GPC-SEC was performed at room temperature using polystyrene as reference standard ( Fig. 10b; Table 4). From the SEC analysis it was found that oligomerization was the active mechanism, resulting in chain lengths of ± 2100 g.mol−1. Though the literature on co-oligomerization of styrene with LAO is scarce, it has been reported that the low molecular weight co-oligomers are the predominant products [57,58]. FT-IR spectroscopic analysis indicated the successful conversion to the co-oligomers. This confirmation was based on the following observations: the presence of the phenyl substituent corresponding to the PS sub-sequence of the co-oligomer was confirmed through the presence of the aromatic C-H stretching frequencies at 3081–3024 cm−1 and the methylene C-H stretching frequencies at 2921–2848 cm−1. Furthermore, the CC stretching frequencies of the phenyl moiety at 1600 cm−1, 1582 cm−1, 1492 cm−1 and 1451 cm−1 was also observed. Lastly, the 757 cm−1 and 695 cm−1 C-H out-of-plane bending frequencies indicated singular substitution of the phenyl moieties [39,40]. Although the addition of the linear pendants to the PS backbone does not introduce any new functionalities to the oligomer, an increasing intensity of the aliphatic C-H stretching frequencies were observed as the linear branch’s chain length increases. This indicated that the linear pendants were indeed incorporated into the oligomeric backbone. NMR spectroscopy was used to correlate the FT-IR results as well as determine the co-oligomer composition (Fig. 10a; Table 4). In 1H NMR (Fig. 9a) the appearance of low intensity olefin proton signals in the 5.2–6.7 ppm range confirmed the successful conversion to PS, whilst also proving evidence for β-H abstraction as the transfer reaction [41,42]. The evidence of transfer reactions indicates that the co-oligomers are not coordinated to the nano-catalysts and exists as free species. The phenyl substituents proton signals was observed in all cases within the 7.19–6.44 ppm, aromatic region. Additionally, the proton signals of the linear branches in the co-oligomer were clearly observed as multiplet signals in the 1.19–0.71 ppm region. The broad nature of the signals in the proton spectra, is indicative of longer chain molecules and thus does not correspond to the unreacted monomers. To correlate the 1H NMR results obtained for the co-polymers, 13C NMR analysis was performed (Fig. 9b) Within the obtained 13C NMR results the appearance of the correct number of signals corresponding to the number of carbon atoms of the LAO. Furthermore, the remainder of the signals corresponded well with the 13C NMR spectra obtained for the homopolymeric PS within this investigation and was correlated to the literature on the co-polymers where available [43]. Similar to the observation made for the coordination homopolymers the presence of the multiplet of signals at ± 146 ppm and ± 44 ppm in place of a singlets is indicative of variations in the co-oligomers microstructures [44]. Lastly, the isotactic (mm)-, heterotactic (mr)- and- syndiotactic (rr) triads at 146.1, 145.7 and 145.2 ppm, respectively, were assigned [45]. The assignments that the products were isotactic-rich atactic co-oligomers like the homo-polystyrene. Thus, the stereo-control exhibited by the nano-catalysts is upheld in the presence of different hetero-monomers. Interestingly, isotacticity of the co-oligomers decreases from 54.3% in the coordination homopolymers to 43.1–46.4% for the co-oligomers as determined using Eq. (1). It was observed that the weight percentage isotacticity increases as the linear branch chain length increases in the manner of in the range of 43.1%, 44.9%, 46.1% and 46.4% for 1-pentene, 1-hexene, 1-heptene and 1-octene, respectively. Lastly, melting point analysis was performed on all the co-oligomers to confirm the tacticity as well as the T g and T m properties of the co-oligomers. A decrease in the Tg of the co-oligomers was clearly observed in comparison to the coordination PS. The co-oligomers had T g’s between 67 and 85 ℃ , whereas T m’s between 211 and 266 ℃ were observed for the co-oligomers. The shifts in the obtained T g and T m temperatures compared to coordination PS is indicative of successful incorporation of the linear branches into the backbone of the oligomers [59,60]. After sufficient characterization of the co-oligomer products, the catalytic nature of the system is scrutinized. The percentage conversion, catalytic activity, molecular weight and PDI for all the co-oligomers were evaluated. Firstly, it was observed that the percentage conversions achieved for the co-oligomers were between 0% and 16%, which was much lower than that of the styrene homopolymers. This was expected due to the dramatic difference between the reactivity ratios of styrene and the LAOs, [61] resulting in decreased percentage conversion and activity at any given reaction time. However, very interestingly a distinct correlation between the achieved activity and the chain length of the LAO was established. It was shown that as the chain length of the LAO increases i.e., C5 to C9, the achieved activity decreases, culminating in no obtainable styrene-nonene co-oligomer ( Fig. 11). This observation can be attributed to increased steric crowding of the propagating chain as the chain length of the LAO increases i.e., the longer the olefin chain, the greater the steric crowding [52,53,62]. It is concluded that the steric crowding introduced by 1-nonene is too great and therefore sterically co-oligomerization is not feasible for this system. Nevertheless, the catalytic activity achieved by the nano-catalysts in the co-oligomerization at ambient conditions was comparable and, in some cases, showed improved activity compared to similar co-polymers reported in the literature using elevated temperatures [59,60]. This alludes to the fact that the use of nano-catalysts are catalytically advantageous even under co-polymerization conditions. Oligomerization is shown to be the active mechanism, probably due to the low reactivity ratios of the LAOs, which could opt for β-H abstraction opposed to the polymerization of immediately sequential linear monomeric units [55,56,61]. Nonetheless, a trend in the achieved polymer molecular weight caused by the linear branch chain length, was established. It was observed that as the linear co-monomer chain length increases, the resulting co-oligomer molecular weight also increases. Given that oligomerization was the active mechanism and not polymerization, the PDIs are less relevant but are deemed low, indicating good catalytic control exhibited by the nano-catalysts. The co-oligomerization presented here, showed that the nano-catalysts can facilitate a variety of substrates for both homo- and co-polymerization processes through the coordination polymerization mechanism, capable of maintaining stereocontrol upon switching from homo- to co-polymerization. This shows that the nano-catalysts are comparable catalysts at reduced reaction conditions [56,61]. 4 Conclusion Here we report further insights into nanoparticle facilitated polymerization and oligomerization processes by the extension of their use to various other monomers. We present the successful coordination homopolymerization of relatively monodispersed polystyrene with medium molecular weights between 20,000 and 40,000 g.mol−1. Subsequently, the catalytic transformation of LAOs such as 1-pentene, 1-hexene, 1-heptene, 1-octene and 1-nonene, which are regarded as waste products from the Fischer-Tropsch process, via the co-polymerization with styrene was reported. The co-polymerization was achieved at low conversions yielding monodispersed co-oligomers as products. Furthermore, a direct link between the branch length of the linear co-monomer and the achieved conversion was established i.e., the increase in linear chain length decreased the achieved conversion due to increased steric crowding. It was also found that the nano-catalysts exhibited a degree of stereocontrol over the propagating polymeric chains as for both the homopolymers and co-oligomers, isotactic-rich atactic polymer/oligomers were found. The activity achieved for the nanoparticle-assisted transformation of styrene was independent of the nature of the ligand as well as the ligand density. Resultingly, a lower ligand density can be selected for styrene polymerization increasing the cost-effectivity of the catalytic process. Lastly, it was shown that nanoparticles as polymerization catalysts are not only comparable to their discrete complex analogs, but they are also capable of manipulating various types of substrates in both homo- and co-polymerization processes and simultaneously exhibiting stereocontrol over the system via the coordination polymerization mechanism. We also present a more cost-effective nickel catalyst’ alternative opposed to the more reported titanium analogs. coredata.dc:description: Based on recent developments on the use of Schiff-base functionalized nickel nanoparticles as pre-catalysts in the polymerization of norbornene, the potential of these nano-systems was further explored using other olefins, both aromatic and aliphatic olefins. Herein, Schiff-base functionalized NiCl2 nanoparticles were further evaluated as potential coordination polymerization catalysts for styrene employing modified methylaluminoxane (MMAO) as a co-catalyst. Furthermore, the first attempted co-polymerization of styrene with α-linear olefins (C5-C9) using nanoparticle-assisted transformation is reported. It was found that the nano-catalysts were capable of the coordination polymerization and co-oligomerization of styrene and gave relatively monodispersed medium molecular weight polymers and short chained co-oligomers with activities comparable to the complex analogs. It was further shown that the activity of the nano-catalysts as well as the Mw and PDI of the polymers/oligomers, were not dependent on the Schiff-base ligand used as capping agent nor its concentration. The nano-catalysts were also shown to exhibit stereocontrol, giving isotactic-rich atactic homo- and co-polymers.
coredata.dc:title: Nano polymerization catalysts: Further insights into nanoparticle-facilitated polymerization of olefins
